Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a field focused on creating intelligent machines that can think, learn, and solve complex problems like humans. The theoretical foundations of AI are rooted in computer science, mathematics, psychology, and cognitive science. In the 2007 paper [1], the authors discuss defining machine intelligence as follows: they overview existing theories and tests of human intelligence developed by psychologists to gain a broad understanding of intelligence's essence (section 2). Their objective is to find common ideas that could be applicable to any system, not just humans (section 3). The paper suggests extracting essential features from well-known informal definitions of human intelligence and mathematically formalizing them to produce a general measure of intelligence for arbitrary machines. They argue that this equation captures the concept of machine intelligence in the broadest reasonable sense ([1]). Regarding the limitations of defining intelligence, the authors mention the difficulty of developing an abstract and highly general notion of intelligence due to its complexity ([1]). They also stress that their formal definition may not fully capture all aspects of human-like intelligence. Historically, definitions of AI have evolved over time, as shown in [1] which discusses mainstream views on human intelligence and other proposed definitions of machine intelligence ([1]). The paper references works such as "Handbook of Intelligence" edited by R. J. Sternberg for an overview of the intellectual, social, and political history of human intelligence ([1]). In terms of the historical evolution of interpretations, Binet's intelligence test in the early 20th century was a significant milestone. It was found that Binet's test results were a good predictor of children's academic performance [1]. However, it is important to note that the development of AI as a distinct field did not begin until the mid-20th century. References:
[1] 0712.3329v1.pdf (2007)
